results.title: 9.5mm Pathé-Baby camera and projector
results.brief_description: The Pathé-Baby camera and projector was an inexpensive and easy-to-use amateur film system introduced in 1922. It used 9.5mm film with central perforations.

constellations_primary.name: 9.5mm Pathe-Baby and parents behaving badly
constellations_primary.description: A look at the link between the Pathé-Baby system and animation, as well as the relationship between cinematic parents and their children.

results.description:
The Pathé-Baby camera and projector was an inexpensive and easy-to-use amateur film system introduced in 1922. It used 9.5mm film with central perforations. This unique film width made it easy to duplicate commercial films for home use, and the hand-cranked projector took up to 60 feet of film.

The portability and simplicity of the Pathé-Baby made the system widely popular internationally. This one was used by pioneering Australian aviator John Robertson Duigan MC to document early aviation and his home life. Having built the first Australian-made aircraft, Duigan definitely had something worth capturing.
description_for_label:
The Pathé-Baby camera and projector was an inexpensive and easy-to-use amateur film system introduced in 1922. It used 9.5mm film with central perforations. This unique film width made it easy to duplicate commercial films for home use, and the hand-cranked projector took up to 60 feet of film.

The portability and simplicity of the Pathé-Baby made the system widely popular internationally. This one was used by pioneering Australian aviator John Robertson Duigan MC to document early aviation and his home life. Having built the first Australian-made aircraft, Duigan definitely had something worth capturing.

results.title: 400 Porto-Arc 16mm projector
results.brief_description: Carbon arc projectors were common until WWII, and it’s rare to see one as late as the 1950s. Because of the intensity of the light in these projectors, they were mostly used in large auditoriums, despite being designed as a lightweight travelling projector.

constellations_primary.name: Movies in movies in a movie museum
constellations_primary.description: The 400 Porto-Arc 16mm projector used the first electric light ever invented, which was perfectly suited for movie projectors. This Constellation explores the movies where characters go to the movies, by two movie-obsessed directors.

results.description:
Carbon arc projectors use the first electric light ever invented. Arc lamps were commonly found in streetlamps during the 1870s, gradually replaced by incandescent light in the early 20th century. But in situations that called for a high-intensity light, like movie projectors, arc lamps still had a role.

Carbon arc projectors were common until WWII, and it’s rare to see one as late as the 1950s. Because of the intensity of the light in these projectors, they were mostly used in large auditoriums, despite being designed as a lightweight travelling projector. They were marketed as the best bet for screening 16mm film in tents, at road shows, at fairs in rural areas and outdoors – as long as there was a power source!
description_for_label:
Carbon arc projectors use the first electric light ever invented. Arc lamps were commonly found in streetlamps during the 1870s, gradually replaced by incandescent light in the early 20th century. But in situations that called for a high-intensity light, like movie projectors, arc lamps still had a role.

Carbon arc projectors were common until WWII, and it’s rare to see one as late as the 1950s. Because of the intensity of the light in these projectors, they were mostly used in large auditoriums, despite being designed as a lightweight travelling projector. They were marketed as the best bet for screening 16mm film in tents, at road shows, at fairs in rural areas and outdoors – as long as there was a power source!

results.title: Bell & Howell Model 601 16mm Film Projector with Speaker, Tripod and Accessories
results.last_on_display_place: Australian Centre for the Moving Image
results.material_description:
001: metal
002: metal and wood
003: cast iron mechanics with a vinyl case
004: speaker in wooden carry case with green vinyl finish and red material.
005: plastic
006: wooden base and metal top.  The metal has tarnished to a green colour and there is brown rust.
007: plastic
008: glass and metal bulbs wrapped in bubble-wrap and housed in original cardboard box.
009: plastic with a metal centre.
010: metal on wooden base.
011: metal case
012: metal (cast-iron?) case
013: metal, leather and plastic
014: plastic rubber
015: red vinyl, wood, rubber, leather and metal.
results.brief_description: Movie projector with accessories. Metal tripod and screw in projector base with a flat platform. Bell and Howell Model 601 projector in case which fits the projector stand. There is also a like projector which isn’t in a case, that was likely a backup or replacement projector for that housed in the canvas. There is the companion Bell and Howell speaker, and also a no brand red-coloured miscellaneous speaker. Housed in the Bell and Howell speaker are two empty reels (1 x 400ft and 1 x 1600ft 16mm), cords, 2x globes, a wooden based film reel winder, and a film splicer. A Bell & Howell Amp/Mixer, and a power box which plugs into speaker/projector as a source of power.

Housed in the Bell and Howell speaker are two empty reels (1 x 400ft and 1 x 1600ft 16mm), cords, 2x globes, a wooden based film reel winder, and a film splicer. results.title: What is happing in #SuezCanal today explained
results.brief_description: On March 23, the sight of a container ship lodged inside the Suez Canal like a car abandoned during a bad parallel park enthralled the world. But the traffic the Ever Given blocked wasn’t insignificant, with hundreds of other vessels barred from delivering supplies and the stock market affected. A catastrophe yes, but one that flooded the internet with hilarious memes, like this one from Zaina Erhaim, which married the logistical absurdity with an equally absurd and iconic scene from Austin Powers: International Man of Mystery.
results.description:
This video features in a responsive display in the museum that presents the moments, stories and memes capturing the zeitgeist by going viral on the internet.

On March 23, the Ever Given container ship got stuck in the Suez Canal like a car abandoned during a bad park, causing ships delivering supplies around the world to be blocked. Though a catastrophe, the internet responded with hilarious memes, like this one that married the logistical absurdity with an equally absurd scene from Austin Powers.
description_for_label:
This video features in a responsive display in the museum that presents the moments, stories and memes capturing the zeitgeist by going viral on the internet.

On March 23, the Ever Given container ship got stuck in the Suez Canal like a car abandoned during a bad park, causing ships delivering supplies around the world to be blocked. Though a catastrophe, the internet responded with hilarious memes, like this one that married the logistical absurdity with an equally absurd scene from Austin Powers.

display_values: The Story of the Moving Image → Moving Minds → MM-09. Catch of the Day

details.label: Materials
display_values: Digital screen recording from @ZainaErhaim's Twitter

results.title: Touring Car Champions for DOS
results.creator_credit: Virtual Sports Interactive and Torus Games
results.material_description: CD-ROM videogame. CD-ROM, CD jewel case and manual in cardboard box
results.brief_description:
Touring Car Champions is based on the Australian Touring Car Championship and the Bathurst 1000. The game features only one track, set in Bathurst, New South Wales. Interestingly, this is depicted through full motion video of the actual track, instead of being recreated or rendered in within the game itself. The video slows down or speeds up based on the player’s speed and the opponent’s cars are 3D models superimposed onto this video.

The game features three modes: The first is Practice, which has no opponents. Quick Race has the player choosing the difficulty of the opponents and racing in a pre-set car. Lastly, The Round is a season-spanning tournament where the player has to work their way up from the amateur division to eventual Touring Car Champion. Along the way, the player can decide what racers, pit crew and car parts to use in each race.

results.title: Emulation of Touring Car Champions for DOS
results.creator_credit: Virtual Sports Interactive and Torus Games
results.brief_description:
Touring Car Champions is based on the Australian Touring Car Championship and the Bathurst 1000. The game features only one track, set in Bathurst, New South Wales. Interestingly, this is depicted through full motion video of the actual track, instead of being recreated or rendered in within the game itself. The video slows down or speeds up based on the player’s speed and the opponent’s cars are 3D models superimposed onto this video.

The game features three modes: The first is Practice, which has no opponents. Quick Race has the player choosing the difficulty of the opponents and racing in a pre-set car. Lastly, The Round is a season-spanning tournament where the player has to work their way up from the amateur division to eventual Touring Car Champion. Along the way, the player can decide what racers, pit crew and car parts to use in each race.

description_for_label:
Touring Car Champions is based on the Australian Touring Car Championship and the Bathurst 1000. The game features only one track, set in Bathurst, New South Wales. Interestingly, this is depicted through full motion video of the actual track, instead of being recreated or rendered in within the game itself. The video slows down or speeds up based on the player’s speed and the opponent’s cars are 3D models superimposed onto this video.

The game features three modes: The first is Practice, which has no opponents. Quick Race has the player choosing the difficulty of the opponents and racing in a pre-set car. Lastly, The Round is a season-spanning tournament where the player has to work their way up from the amateur division to eventual Touring Car Champion. Along the way, the player can decide what racers, pit crew and car parts to use in each race.
